Author: bootload
Content:
"... The evening arrived; the boys took their places. The master, in his cook's uniform, stationed himself at the copper; his pauper assistants ranged themselves behind him; the gruel was served out; and a long grace was said over the short commons. The gruel disappeared; the boys whispered each other, and winked at Oliver; while his next neighbors nudged him. Child as he was, he was desperate with hunger, and reckless with misery. He rose from the table; and advancing to the master, basin and spoon in hand, said: somewhat alarmed at his own temerity:

'Please, sir, I want some more.' ..." ~ http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext96/olivr11.txt

In other words attack Tims poor stand on "software as a service" doing everyone a disservice as software might again slip into hands of Dickensian like masters where users are reduced to begging for permission to access to fix a piece of buggy software critical to their business and communication. See 'Eben Moglen' challenge for Tim ~ http://www.linux.com/feature/118201

"... Let's not turn this into digg, shall we? ..."

ie: Meaning no 'argumentum ad hominem' attacks on every Tim, Dick or Jane. Go for the ideas, not the man ~ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ad_hominem

Author: aswanson
Content: I find it interesting that the degeneration of these sites into 'mob rule' is the exact thing the founders of the constitution anticipated and put safeguards in place against.  Who said,'The best argument against democracy is a conversation with the average person'?  Maybe we can find some answers in the philosophy of government...

Author: rms
Content:
You summed it up yourself. The fundamental difference between a service and a piece of desktop software is that you can't steal it.

In a society where everyone has access to free software and an internal moral compass is the only thing that deters us from piracy, it doesn't make a whole lot of sense to release desktop software with no service component.

Author: palish
Content: This is great!  Great writing Paul, thank you for examining this.

Author: bootload
Title: Twitter Is Now An Extension Of My Blogging

Author: ivankirigin
Content:
When this was posted, ~50,000 songs were uploaded. Now it is at 75,800. Nice

I've has some trouble uploading though.

Author: palish
Content:
Okay. So for someone like me, in a position where I have very little money and I want to get out of that situation, to hear "Whatever people make should be free" is just silly. Yes, open source is wonderful, and I really want to contribute to it. But needing to feed myself everyday and to pay for my car and a place to live takes precedence.

Would you tell PG that Viaweb should've been free? Why? Because it's a service? There's no fundamental difference between a service and a piece of desktop software, except you can't steal it.
